00010  **********************************************************************/
00011 
00012 #if !defined(RANDOMLIB_LEADINGZEROS_HPP)
00013 #define RANDOMLIB_LEADINGZEROS_HPP \
00014   "$Id: 51773297717864d905d43817dd910e302287168f $"
00015 
00016 namespace RandomLib {
00017   /**
00018    * \brief Count of leading zeros.
00019    *
00020    * Count of leading zero bits after the binary point in a real number
00021    * uniformly distributed in (0,1).  (This is equivalent to the geometric
00022    * distribution with probability 1/2.)  For example
00023    * \code
00024    *   #include <RandomLib/LeadingZeros.hpp>
00025    *
00026    *   RandomLib::Random r; // A RandomGenerator works here too
00027    *   std::cout << "Seed set to " << r.SeedString() << "\n";
00028    *   LeadingZeros zeros;
00029    *   std::cout << "Count of leading zeros:";
00030    *   for (size_t i = 0; i < 20; ++i)
00031    *       std::cout << " " << zeros(r);
00032    *   std::cout << "\n";
00033    * \endcode
00034    **********************************************************************/
00035   class LeadingZeros {
00036   public:
00037     /**
00038      * Return the number of zero bits after the binary point in a real number
00039      * uniformly distributed in (0,1).  Thus \e k is returned with probability
00040      * 1/2<sup><i>k</i>+1</sup>.  Because MT19937 is \e not a perfect random
00041      * number generator, this always returns a result in [0, 19937).
00042      *
00043      * @tparam Random the type of the random generator.
00044      * @param[in,out] r a random generator.
00045      * @return the random sample.
00046      **********************************************************************/
00047     template<class Random> unsigned operator()(Random& r) const throw();
00048   };
00049 
00050   template<class Random>
00051   unsigned LeadingZeros::operator()(Random& r) const throw() {
00052     // It's simpler to count the number of trailing ones in each w-bit block
00053     // stopping when we get to a zero bit.
00054     //
00055     // Process a word in chunks of size m.  The algorithm here can deal with
00056     // any m assuming that z is modified accordingly.  m = 4 is an approximate
00057     // optimum.
00058     //
00059     // Can also adapt this routine to use RandomNumber::highest_bit_idx
00060     // instead.  However the result is considerably slower.
00061     const int m = 4;
00062     STATIC_ASSERT(m <= Random::width, "LeadingZeros: m too large");
00063     // mask with m low bits set
00064     const typename Random::result_type mask = ~(Random::max << m);
00065     // Number of trailing 1 bits in [0, 1<<m).  However, correct results are
00066     // also obtained with any permutation of this array.  This particular
00067     // permutation is useful since the initial 1/2, 1/4, etc. can be used for
00068     // m-1, m-2, etc.  To generate the array for the next higher m, append a
00069     // duplicate of the array and increment the last entry by one.
00070     const unsigned z[1 << m] =
00071       { 0, 1, 0, 2, 0, 1, 0, 3, 0, 1, 0, 2, 0, 1, 0, 4, };
00072     typename Random::result_type x = r();
00073     for (unsigned b = m, n = 0; b < Random::width; b += m) {
00074       n += z[x & mask];         // count trailing 1s in chunk
00075       if (n < b)                // chunk contains a 0
00076         return n;
00077       x >>= m;                  // shift out the chunk we've processed
00078     }
00079     // x is all ones (prob 1/2^w); process the next word.
00080     return Random::width + operator()(r);
00081   }
00082 } // namespace RandomLib
00083 
00084 #endif  // RANDOMLIB_LEADINGZEROS_HPP
